Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-Brazil Frontiers of Science and Engineering Symposium
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will help to support the first U.S.-Brazil Frontiers of Science and Engineering Symposium (USBFOS&E) organized by the National Academy of Science (NAS) and the National Academy of Engineering (NAE), respectively, in partnership with the National Academy of Sciences of Brazil. The symposium, to be held in Brazil in early 2014, is designed to facilitate exchange and collaboration across scientific and engineering disciplines and to enhance networks among early-career scientists and engineers. This would be the first bilateral Frontiers meeting involving both young scientists and engineers at the same meeting, and will also be the first to be held in Latin America.

About 60-70 outstanding early-career scientists and engineers from the United States and Brazil (30-35 from each side) are expected to participate and attend this symposium. A program organizing committee, led by co-chairs from the U.S. and Brazil and consisting of additional members, will identify topics and speakers. The symposium format will include formal sessions with presentations by speakers on leading edge research, emerging technologies, and with multiple opportunities for informal interactions across science and engineering fields. Similar symposia in other regions have fostered interdisciplinary and international collaborations, and have served as a reference point for many of the emerging frontiers in research and innovation in the U.S. Presentations from the USBFOS&E will be posted on the NAS and NAE-FOE web sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Kavli Frontiers of Science (KFOS) and the Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) programs were started by the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering, respectively, to facilitate exchange and collaboration across scientific and engineering disciplines and to enhance networks among early-career scientists and engineers. This activity ultimately advances innovation and the US research enterprise. In addition to the annual KFOS and FOE symposia involving US-based attendees, there are KFOS programs with Germany, Japan, China, India, Indonesia, South Korea, and Israel; and FOE programs with Germany, Japan, India, China, and the European Union. The symposia are designed to bring together a select group of scientists and engineers (ages 30-45) from academia, industry, and government labs to discuss pioneering scientific and engineering research and leading-edge technical work in various scientific and engineering fields and industry sectors. The goal of the symposia is to promote an interdisciplinary transfer of knowledge and methodology that could lead to collaborative networks of scientists and engineers within the United States and between scientists and engineers from the United States and partnering countries. These same goals apply to the Brazil-US Frontiers of Science and Engineering symposium. 

The Brazil-US Frontiers of Science and Engineering Symposium was held  March 17-19, 2014, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. There were 60 attendees, excluding staff and guests. Brazilian and US scientists and engineers gave presentations on four topics: 1) Bioengineering and Public Health: Biomedical Materials and Devices for Bridging the Biotic-Abiotic Interface, 2) Precision Nanotech: The Next Generation of Nanoengineering and Nanomaterials, 3) Biofuels, and 4) Sustainability and Resilient Cities: Challenges and Opportunities. In addition, there were poster sessions and numerous networking activities. Videos of the presentations are posted on the symposium homepage at www.nasonline.org/busfose14.
